body_text.text: The single subunit RNA polymerases (RNAPs) form a widespread family of enzymes that represents a subset of the even larger pol A superfamily of nucleic acid poly-merases (1)(2)(3).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The first recognized member of this superfamily was DNA Pol I from Escherichia coli, and the best characterized member of the single-subunit RNAPs is that from bacteriophage T7.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In addition to forming part of the genomes of many phages, single-subunit RNAP homologues are encoded in all eukaryotic nuclear genomes and are functionally expressed in chloroplasts and mitochondria, where they transcribe these organelles' messenger and ribosomal RNAs, and also prime replication of their genomes (1,2,4,5).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Comparison of the primary and tertiary structures of the single-subunit RNAPs reveals that they all display an architecture common to the broader pol A superfamily (3).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: All of these enzymes conserve a polymerase domain that contains the catalytic site and the template binding cleft, which is shaped like a cupped right hand with thumb, palm and fingers subdomains.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Different members of this family also exhibit structurally distinct domains, N-terminal to the polymerase domain, which are responsible for distinct functions of different family members.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: DNAP I, e.g. contains an N-terminal exonucleoytic proofreading domain (6), while T7 RNAP displays an N-terminal domain (NTD) that participates in sequence-specific promoter interaction and binding of the nascent RNA (7,8).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The recently described structure of the human mitochondrial RNAP (MtRNAP) repeats this pattern, as it resembles a T7 RNAP molecule to which is appended, at its N-terminus, a ∼370-residue Nterminal extension domain that is structurally unrelated to any elements that have been described in the phage enzymes (9).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The eukaryotic organellar RNAPs are properly described as single-subunit enzymes, since all catalytic activities reside in a single polypeptide which carries out processive, template-directed RNA chain extension without the need for any accessory proteins.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: However, the mitochondrial RNAPs are functionally distinct from the phage enzymes in that they require one or more transcription factors to open the promoter and initiate transcription, though these factors are dispensable during transcript elongation (10,11).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Because fundamental structure-mechanism relationships in the phage RNAPs have been so effectively characterized, the most important questions for the MtRNAPs concern those aspects of structure and mechanism that are distinct from the phage polymerases.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In particular, how does the initiation factor(s) function in the transcription cycle?
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To address this we have used both negative staining and cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) to generate three-dimensional (3D) reconstructions of yeast MtR-NAP:promoter complexes (quasi-ICs); initiation complexes (ICs) comprised of promoter, MtRNAP and the yeast mitochondrial transcription factor (MTF1), and elongation complexes comprised of MtRNAP, RNA and DNA.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Together with biochemical data these 3D reconstructions reveal that the transcription factor drives promoter melting through multiple mechanisms and that, while the MtRNAP goes through a conformational cycle during transcription that bears similarity to that seen in the phage RNAPs and other pol A enzymes, the MtRNAP conformational cycle is distinct in that it is regulated by interactions with the transcription factor.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: MTF1 and MtRNAP mutants were constructed with the Stratagene polymerase chain reaction site directed mutagenesis kit following manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: Enzyme and template preparations

body_text.text: Expression and purification of mutant polymerases and MTF1 transcription factor were carried out as described (10), except that proteins were expressed by growing cells to OD of 0.4 at 37 • C, following which cultures were transferred to 16 • C for 30 min, at which point isopropyl ␤-D-1thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) was added to induce expression and the cultures were incubated for a further 24-48 h at 16 • C. Purified proteins were stored at −20 • C in buffer containing 10 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 0.5 M NaCl, 1 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), 5 mM dithiothreitol (DTT) and 50% glycerol.
body_text.section: Enzyme and template preparations

body_text.text: DNAs or RNAs were synthesized by Integrated DNA Technologies, dissolved at 1 mM concentration in 20 mM Tris pH 8.0, 50 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, and subsequently annealed by mixing with equimolar amounts of complementary oligonucleotides in the same buffer, heating to 95 • C for 5 min, and slow cooling for 2 h at room temperature before being stored at −20 • C. Complexes for EM analysis were prepared by mixing equimolar amounts of yeast MtRNAP and annealed templates (with or without equimolar MTF1) followed by dialysis for 12-16 h at 4 • C into 10 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 50 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM DTT and 50% glycerol with final concentration of complexes of 10 M. Streptavidin labeled complexes were prepared by subsequently adding streptavidin (Sigma-Aldrich) at 3-fold molar excess (to limit binding of multiple complexes to the tetrameric streptavidin) to complexes which had been assembled from DNAs synthesized with biotin at the 5 -ends.
body_text.section: Enzyme and template preparations

body_text.text: To assess complex homogeneity, as well as to compare complex stability on different promoter templates in competition experiments, native polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) was used.
body_text.section: Enzyme and template preparations

body_text.text: Four microlitre of the assembled complexes were electrophoresed on 8-25% polyacrylamide gels with native buffer strips on a Pharmacia PhastSystem electrophoresis apparatus.
body_text.section: Enzyme and template preparations

body_text.text: Complexes were visualized by staining with coomassie blue or with a Molecular Dynamics Storm Imager with complexes assembled with DNAs labeled at their 5 -ends with fluorescein.
body_text.section: Enzyme and template preparations

body_text.text: In vitro transcription reactions were carried out at room temperature for 30 min in 10 l in transcription buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 10 mM NaCl, 20 mM MgCl 2 , 10 mM DTT) and nucleoside triphosphates (NTPs) at concentrations indicated in individual figure legends and 0.2 M template.
body_text.section: Transcription assays

body_text.text: RNA synthesis was initiated by addition of 0.4 M yMtRNAP and 0.8 M MTF1.
body_text.section: Transcription assays

body_text.text: Transcripts were labeled by inclusion of 1% (v/v) 3000 ci/mM 10 mCi/ml [␣-33 P] adenosine triphosphate (ATP) from ICN.
body_text.section: Transcription assays

body_text.text: Reaction samples taken at the time points specified in individual figure legends were quenched by addition of an equal volume of stop buffer (95% formamide, 20 mM EDTA, 0.01% xylene cyanol).
body_text.section: Transcription assays

body_text.text: Transcription products were resolved by electrophoresis in 20% (w/v) polyacrylamide gels (19% acrylamide, 1% bis-acrylamide, 7 M urea) in Tris/Borate/EDTA (TBE) buffer and analyzed with a Molecular Dynamics Phosphorimager.
body_text.section: Transcription assays

body_text.text: The sensitivity of MTF1 to carboxypeptidase digestion was assessed in experiments with 10 M MTF1 with or without promoter DNA or MtRNAP in transcription buffer (minus DTT) with 0.01 /ml of carboxypeptidase Y. Reaction aliquots at different times were taken and stopped by adding 1% v/v of a 100 mM PMSF solution in isopropanol.
body_text.section: Carboxypeptidase Y sensitivity

body_text.text: Digests were analyzed by denaturing (sodium dodecyl sulphate) PAGE on 10% polyacrylamide/bis-acrylamide gels.
body_text.section: Carboxypeptidase Y sensitivity

body_text.text: The band corresponding to MTF1 was excised and analyzed by mass spectrometry.
body_text.section: Carboxypeptidase Y sensitivity

body_text.text: For Iron (S)-1-p-bromoacetamidobenzyl EDTA (Fe-BABE) cleavage experiments the 5 -end of the template (T) or non-template (NT) strands of the DNAs were labeled with [␥ -32P]ATP (4000 Ci/mmol; ICN) with T4 polynucleotide kinase (Invitrogen) as described (12).
body_text.section: DNA cleavage with Fe-BABE conjugated proteins

body_text.text: Fe-BABE (Dojindo Laboratories) was conjugated to cysteine substituted MTF1 or MtRNAPs as described (13).
body_text.section: DNA cleavage with Fe-BABE conjugated proteins

body_text.text: ICs halted at +0, +3 or +7, were formed at room temperature in transcription buffer containing labeled bubble or duplex yeast 14 s rRNA promoter template at 0.01 M, MtR-NAP at 0.03 M and MTF1 at 0.06 M. After a 10 min incubation with varying NTP mixes to form complexes halted at different positions, cleavage was initiated by addition of sodium ascorbate and H 2 O 2 as described (14).
body_text.section: DNA cleavage with Fe-BABE conjugated proteins

body_text.text: Cleavage reactions were quenched after 5 s by addition of one reaction volume of stop buffer (95% formamide, 20 mM EDTA, 0.1% xylene cyanol).
body_text.section: DNA cleavage with Fe-BABE conjugated proteins

body_text.text: Cleavage products were analyzed by electrophoresis in denaturing 15% polyacrylamide gels (14.2% acrylamide, 0.8% bisacrylamide and 7 M urea) and visualized on a Molecular Dynamics Pphosphorimager.
body_text.section: DNA cleavage with Fe-BABE conjugated proteins

body_text.text: Cleavage positions were mapped by reference to Maxam-Gilbert G + A ladder prepared as described (15).
body_text.section: DNA cleavage with Fe-BABE conjugated proteins

body_text.text: Aliquots of the different transcription complexes (quasi-IC, upstream labeled quasi-IC, IC, upstream and downstreamlabeled IC, EC, upstream and downstream labeled EC, spRNAPIV elongation complex (EC) and downstream labeled spRNAPIV EC) were applied onto previously glow-discharged carbon-coated copper/rhodium grids and stained with 2% uranyl acetate.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Images were recorded under minimal-dose conditions on Kodak SO-163 film, in a JEOL JEM1200EXII microscope operated at 100 kV and 60 000 magnification.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Micrographs were digitized using a ZEISS scanner with the step size of 14 m, resulting in a pixel size of 2.33Å.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: For cryoEM, aliquots of IC and EC were applied onto glow-discharged, holey carbon grids (carbon-coated Quantifoil R 1.2/ R1.3 300 mesh grids) containing an additional continuous thin layer of carbon, and plunged into liquid ethane.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Images were acquired under minimal dose conditions with a Tecnai F20 transmission electron microscope at 200 kV.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: The images were taken at magnification of ∼110 000 using a 16 megapixel (Mpx) FEI Eagle CCD camera with a step size of 15 m, thus the original pixel size of the acquired images was 1.37Å.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Cryo-EM micrographs were downsampled by a factor of 2 or 3 (EC and IC, respectively).
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: The contrast transfer function of the each acquired image was estimated using CTFFIND 3 program (16) and corrected at the micrograph level.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Individual particles were selected manually and extracted using XMIPP software (17) (Supplementary Figure S (19)) were carried out with normalized particles.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Homogeneous populations were obtained and averaged for a final two-dimensional (2D) characterization.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Several starting reference models and initial 3D reconstruction steps based on iterative angular refinement were performed using the EMAN software package (20).
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: In general the initial volumes were created upon the class averages generated in the previous step, using a common lines approach or by using artificial noisy models and Gaussian blobs with the rough dimensions of the protein complexes.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: In the case of the streptavidin labeled complexes and those complexes analyzed by cryo-EM, the previously obtained EM maps of non-labeled or negatively-stained complexes were filtered to 70Å, and used as the initial models.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: The different strategies converged to similar solutions, and one of the models was selected to complete the refinement (Supplementary Figure S2C).
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: However, in the case of heterogeneity (EC cryo-EM; streptavidin-biotin labeled ICs) the most stable model was subjected to maximum likelihood 3D classification (ML3D) (18) to address this problem.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: The separated particles were processed using EMAN and the whole 3D reconstruction cycle was repeated de novo.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: The resolution of the reconstructions was determined by the FSC 0.5 criterion (Supplementary Figure S3), and these values were used to low-pass filter the final volumes.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: The visualization of density maps and atomic structures was performed using UCSF Chimera (21).
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: The dockings were firstly performed manually and then rendered by Chimera, using a real time correlation criterion between the reference model (final model) and the surface created from the atomic structure/model.
body_text.section: Electron microscopy and image processing

body_text.text: Formation of the yeast mitochondrial initiation complex (IC) requires yeast MtRNAP (1324 residues) and MTF1 (341 residues) which, together, form a stable complex with a duplex mitochondrial promoter DNA (11,22).
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: A stable complex can also be assembled between the MtRNAP alone and a 'pre-melted' promoter (Supplementary Figures S1A-C; bubble promoter or 'IC DNA') bearing sequence changes in the NT strand to create a mismatched +2 to −4 region (10).
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: Because we wanted to identify MTF1 and MtRNAP in the 3D reconstruction of the IC, we sought to image ICs formed without MTF1 (quasi-ICs) as well as true ICs formed with both proteins.
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: It is, however, possible that complexes formed on the pre-melted promoters do not genuinely recapitulate the structures of complexes formed on fully duplex promoters.
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: We therefore used chemical nucleases tethered to cysteines introduced into MTF1 or MtR-NAP to compare the structure of ICs formed on duplex versus pre-melted promoters.
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: We observed that these nucleases cut the promoter DNA at nearly identical locations on both types of promoters, and that, upon addition of NTPs that allowed extension of the RNA to different lengths, these cleavage sites shifted identically on both the fully duplex and pre-melted promoters ( Supplementary Figures S1D and E).
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: The ICs formed on the pre-melted and duplex promoters are therefore structurally and functionally similar.
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: A total of 12848 images of negatively stained particles formed with the MtRNAP and a 29 bp promoter DNA in which the −2 to +4 region was heteroduplex were used to generate a 3D reconstruction of a quasi-IC ( Figure 1A and B; see also Supplementary Figures S2 and S3A), revealing a compact structure.
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: The pol A class polymerases display a polymerase domain with the shape of a cupped right hand that forms a cleft in which the DNA binds.
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: This central cleft is apparent in the 3D reconstruction of the quasi-IC, but is narrower than typically seen in other pol-A class polymerases ( Figure 1C).
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: The narrowness of this cleft in the quasi-IC seems to correspond to the 'clenched' conformation with a constricted central binding cleft observed in human MtRNAP (23) ( Figure 1A), and this notion is strengthened by a better docking correlation value with this atomic structure (PDB ID: 3SPA; 0.85) than with that of mtRNAP EC (PDB ID: 4BOC; 0.84) ( Figure 1B), but specially by a 3D reconstruction of quasi-IC with DNA labeled with streptavidin at its upstream end ('upstream streptavidin quasi-IC'), generated from 16514 particles (Supplementary Figure S3B; 18Å resolution) in which the streptavidin molecule (and therefore the 5 -end of the NT-strand DNA) is located closer to the polymerase domain.
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: These results point to the yeast MtRNAP in quasi-IC having a clenched conformation
body_text.section: Structural characterization of yeast MtRNAP IC without MTF1 ('quasi IC')

body_text.text: To compare the quasi-IC conformation to that of a true IC, we carried out a 3D reconstruction of the IC at 22 A resolution ( Figures 1D, 2A and Supplementary Figure  S3D) using 15917 negatively stained particles formed with yeast MtRNAP, MTF1 and the 29 bp pre-melted promoter DNA (Supplementary Figure S1B).
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: Both our native gels and inspection of EM fields of negatively-stained quasi-ICs and ICs indicated that the quasi-IC had a tendency to oligomerize that was suppressed in the IC.
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: The excep- tional homogeneity of the IC particles and their relatively large size (∼210 kDa) prompted us to attempt an EM reconstruction of the IC by cryo-EM.
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: A total of 10 893 particles were used to generate a 15Å resolution 3D reconstruction of the IC ( Figure 2B and Supplementary Figure  S3C).
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: Comparison of the IC reconstructions obtained by negative staining and cryo-EM show them to be very similar (compare Figure 2A and B; see also Supplementary Figure  S3C and D).
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: We therefore aligned these two reconstructions and both docked well with the atomic structure of human MtRNAPEC (the correlation coefficient values were 0.84 and 0.81 for the docking into the EM structures originating from frozen and negatively stained samples, respectively).
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: In human MtRNAP, the transition from the clenched, DNAfree to the open, elongation state involves the rotation of the palm and fingers domains by 10 • and 15 • , respectively.
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: The resulting conformation of human MtRNAP in EC resembles to that of the intermediate IC of T7 RNAP, the state with a 7 nts long RNA (24).
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: Thus, we suggest that the conformation of MtRNAP in the IC is closer to the EC than to the clenched form found in the quasi-IC.
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: Indeed, the IC as a whole, and the central, template-binding cleft, were found to be wider than in the quasi-IC (compare the cavities in the structures shown in Figure 1C and D).
body_text.section: Yeast MtRNAP IC with MTF1 assumes an open conformation

body_text.text: The shape of the largest density element in the difference map obtained by subtraction of the IC from the quasi-IC is similar to the atomic structure of MTF1 ( Figure 1E).
body_text.section: Localization of MTF1 in the IC

body_text.text: MTF1 is a dumbbell-shaped molecule comprised of a larger mixed helical/sheet NTD and a smaller, helical C-terminal domain (25).
body_text.section: Localization of MTF1 in the IC

body_text.text: Overall, the molecule has concave and convex sides that, together with the differences in the sizes of the two lobes of the dumbbell, allow us to orient the MTF1 with the C-terminal domain at the narrower end of the difference density and with the concave side facing the MtRNAP (Figures 1E and 2).
body_text.section: Localization of MTF1 in the IC

body_text.text: This positions MTF1 in the IC with its concave and more electropositive side facing the electropositive surface of the MtRNAP which forms the DNA and RNA binding sites of the polymerase (Figures 2 and 3; see also Supplementary Figures S3C and D).
body_text.section: Localization of MTF1 in the IC

body_text.text: The two 3D reconstructions therefore indicate that MTF1 binds the IC so as to sandwich the DNA between the electropositive surfaces of the polymerase and the transcription factor.
body_text.section: Localization of MTF1 in the IC

body_text.text: To better reveal how the DNA binds in these complexes we carried out 3D reconstructions of negatively stained ICs formed with DNAs in which either the upstream (5 -NT strand end) or downstream (5 -T strand end) segments were labeled with biotin and then reacted with streptavidin.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: The 3D reconstruction of the IC with streptavidin labeling the upstream end of DNA ('upstream streptavidin IC') reveals an extra density, appropriate for accommodating the streptavidin molecule, connected to the NTD of the MtRNAP by a tube of density (Supplementary Figure S3F).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: Interestingly, the position of the streptavidin matches the position of the upstream DNA termini of the aligned 3E2E atomic structure, the structure of T7RNAP IC with a 7 nts long RNA ( Figure 4B).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: Furthermore, this part of the DNA is located near the positively charged cleft and at the end of the C-terminal domain (C-terminal tail) of MTF1, the MtR-NAP's C-terminal domain, the AT-rich recognition loop and intercalating ␤ hairpin, which as seen in the T7RNAP IC, inserts between the T and NT strands at the upstream edge of the transcription bubble (26,27).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: To identify the downstream segment of the DNA we generated a 3D reconstruction of an IC in which the downstream DNA end was labeled with streptavidin bound to biotin linked to the 5 -end of the T strand ('downstream streptavidin IC'), revealing an extra density that is not occupied by the atomic model of the IC (Supplementary Figure S3E).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: This density is appropriate in size and shape to accommodate the 50 kDa streptavidin tetramer, and sits adjacent to the N-terminal extension ( Figure 4A).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: The position of the downstream end of DNA in 3E2E clashes with the NTD of MTF1, which suggests its placement deeper in the extended binding cleft formed by the MtRNAP and MTF1, also indicating it to be less accessible to streptavidin binding.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: Thus, the positions of upstream and downstream termini of DNA in the yeast  (25) in surface representation with −, + and uncharged regions in red, blue and white, respectively.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: The DNA is in stick representation with the T-strand in cyan and the NT-strand in green.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: The DNA is placed on MTF1 as proposed in our IC model based on steric considerations, EM data, the positions of the intercalating hairpin (stacked on the −4 bp) and active site aspartates (nearest the T-strand +2 ribose), and the positions of the sites cut by Fe-BABE conjugated to different sites on MTF1.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: In each panel the position of the residue(s) to which Fe-BABE was conjugated is labeled and highlighted in yellow, and the centers of the sites of cleavage by those conjugates are indicated by showing the corresponding DNA nucleotides in space-filling representation.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: For the conjugates to residues 332 and 340 , which correspond to residues on the disordered C-terminal tail of MTF1, the magenta arrow shows the possible position of the C-terminal tail based on the observation that conjugates to either of these residues cut within the unwound region of the promoter.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: IC are close to their position in the T7RNAP IC with a 7 nts long RNA (the late IC).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: This, together with the structural resemblance of these polymerases strongly suggests that yeast MtRNAP in complex with MTF1 acquires a conformation similar to the T7RNAP late IC.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: This raises a question of how the quasi-IC, with its narrower cleft, binds DNA.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: When the 3D reconstructions of quasi-IC and IC, both with DNA labeled with streptavidin at their upstream end are compared (Supplementary Figure  S3B and F, respectively), it can be observed that the streptavidin in the quasi-IC is located closer to the polymerase domain than in IC (compare Figure 4B and C).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: Thus, binding of MTF1 is associated with an increased bending of the DNA in the complex and binding of the upstream segment of the promoter toward regions on the MtRNAP NTD(s), consistent with previously reported differential bending of promoter DNA by yeast MtRNAP alone versus the yeast MtRNAP:MTF1 complex (28).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: A similar change in DNA bending is observed in T7RNAP in the initiation steps of transcription--upon the incorporation of the 7th nu-cleotide to the nascent RNA molecule, the N-terminal part of the enzyme (residues 72-152 and 191-267) and the specificity loop are rotated ∼45 • (29).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: This rigid body rotation does not affect the contacts with the promoter, causing its additional bending.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: We have aligned the atomic structure of the T7RNAP IC with a 3 nts RNA (PDB ID: 1QLN (30) with the docked atomic structure of human MtRNAP.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: If the upstream edges of transcription bubbles are taken as a reference point (since the intercalating ␤ hairpins which insert at the upstream edge of the transcription bubble play similar roles in T7RNAP and yeast MtRNAP transcription initiation (27)), then the upstream end of the IC DNA used in this study can be modeled on the DNA of 1QLN ( Figure 4D and E).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: The modeled position is in the range of the upstream streptavidin molecule that represents the experimentally defined position of the upstream DNA terminus (compare Figure 4C and E).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: The conformation of T7RNAP without the DNA and with the DNA and 3 nts long RNA, is similar.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: However, the specificity loop and ␤intercalating hairpin become structured upon DNA bind-Nucleic Acids Research, 2014, Vol. 42, No. 17 11253 ing. The same can be observed for these elements when the DNA-free and DNA-bound structures of human MtRNAP are compared.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: This, together with the position of the upstream end of the DNA in the quasi-IC, which matches that in the T7RNAP IC with 3 nts RNA, suggest that, in the absence of MTF1, DNA-free and DNA-bound MtRNAP assume a similar conformation.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the IC

body_text.text: To test and refine our structural model of IC generated from the EM images of the quasi-IC and IC, and of the streptavidin-labeled complexes, we used the chemical nuclease p-bromoacetamidobenzyl ethylenediaminetetraacetate (Fe-BABE (31)) conjugated to MTF1 cysteines.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: Upon reaction with peroxide, Fe-BABE generates a local burst of diffusible hydroxyl radicals that cut nearby DNA strands, with the intensity of cutting determined by distance and accessibility.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: MTF1 conjugated with Fe-BABE cut both T and NT DNA strands in an IC (Supplementary Figure S4B).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: To determine which of the various MTF1 cysteines was conjugated with the Fe-BABE that was generating these cuts, we individually mutated each of the two surface exposed cysteines on the DNA-binding face of MTF1 (C69 and C192) to serines (mutation of buried cysteine residues caused MTF1 to aggregate during expression. There are two other surface exposed cysteines in MTF1: C220 and C320. C220 is on the side the opposite to that which is identified as binding DNA, while C320 is within the C-terminal tail of MTF1 that is disordered in the crystal structure of MTF1 alone).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: Mutation of C69 did not affect cleavage patterns (not shown), but the C192S mutation almost completely eliminated the cleavage observed with the wild-type protein (Supplementary Figure S4A and B), indicating that cutting was due to Fe-BABE conjugated to C192 (a C192F mutation has been reported to compromise MTF1 function but we found that a C192S mutant had WT activity (Supplementary Figure S4I-M), suggesting that the isosteric serine substitution is less disruptive of MTF1 activity than the phenylalanine substitution).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: We then generated nine other individual cysteine substitutions in the C69S/C192S mutant MTF1 background, expressed and purified these mutants, and conjugated them with Fe-BABE.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: All of the mutants were in surface exposed residues and were found to be similar in activity to the WT protein (Supplementary Figure S4I).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: ICs were formed with these Fe-BABE conjugated MTF1 mutants on a 63 bp DNA containing the active 14 s mitochondrial promoter with base changes introduced into the −4 to +2 region of the NT strand to create a heteroduplex region to enhance IC stability (cutting patterns on fully duplex promoters were modestly weaker but otherwise similar to those on the bubble promoter; Supplementary Figures S1B and S4A-H).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: The DNA in the ICs was labeled at the 5 -end of either the T or NT strand with 33P and cutting was activated by adding peroxide to open complexes (no NTPs), or complexes in which NTPs allowing RNA extension to three or seven nucleotides were present.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: The data set of all these cutting patterns is presented in Supplementary Figures S4A-H, and is summarized in Figure 3.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: The cleavage patterns of the conjugated MTF1 proteins were consistent with the model suggested by the EM 3D reconstructions, MTF1 was placed in the IC so that the duplex down-and upstream segments of the DNA were near the positively charged surface of the NTD and the positively charged region at the border of the N-and C-terminal domains, respectively (Figure 3).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: The most N-terminal conjugate was at residue 78 and cleaved DNA only at positions downstream of the transcription bubble (Supplementary Figure S4A), while the most C-terminal conjugates within the C-terminal domain (at position 296 and 300) only cut DNA upstream of the unwound region (Supplementary Figure S4F).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: Conjugates at intermediate positions (192/230/240) cut both up-and downstream DNA (Supplementary Figures S4B, D and E), consistent with the DNA being sharply bent in the IC so that both up-and downstream DNA segments were accessible to hydroxyl radicals generated at these residues.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: The finer scale features of these cutting patterns also helped to refine the approximate location of MTF1 and DNA in the IC: cutting by conjugates at position 192 was nearest to the apex of the DNA bend (at positions −7/−3/+9/+10, while cutting by the conjugate at 230 was furthest from the unwound region (−17/−11/−8/+12/+18/+21) and the conjugate at 240 cut at intermediate positions (−11/−8/+9/+11).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: These cutting sites therefore indicated that MTF1 and the DNA should be modeled so that residues 192, 240 and 230 define an axis approximately centered on the apex of the bent DNA and extending parallel to the up-and downstream duplexes, with residue 192 closest to the apex and residue 230 most distant (Figure 3).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: This placement of MTF1 is consistent with the conclusion that the transcription factor interacts with the unwound NT-strand to favor promoter melting, and with our observations that MTF1 binds quasi-ICs formed with promoters that contain a melted NT-strand more strongly than promoters that are missing the melted NT-strand (Supplementary Figure S4J-M).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: Cutting by conjugates attached to residues in the MTF1 C-terminal tail was also informative.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: The last 16 residues of the MTF1 C-terminal tail, starting from the residue 325, are disordered in the crystal structure of the protein alone (25).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: Conjugates at residues 332 or 340 within this C-terminal tail cut the NT strand in the IC between −2 and +7, and the T strand between −5 and −2 (Figure 3 and Supplementary Figure S4H).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: These cuts are either within or immediately up-or downstream of the unwound DNA in the IC and suggest that, upon binding DNA, the C-terminal tail becomes ordered and inserts between the melted DNA strands where it may contribute to promoter opening.
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: Consistent with this, we observed that MTF1 binding to the IC protected its C-terminus from digestion by carboxypetidase ( Supplementary Figure S5A).
body_text.section: Chemical nucleases tethered to MTF1 inform IC modeling

body_text.text: The functional role of the C-terminal tail of MTF1 was then tested by comparing the transcriptional activity and stability of ICs formed with full-length MTF1 or MTF1 with the 17 most C-terminal residues deleted (residues 325-341; corresponding to the disordered region in the MTF1 crystal structure; MTF Cterm).
body_text.section: The MTF1 C-terminal tail contributes to promoter opening

body_text.text: We observed that on du-plex promoters, the transcriptional activity in reactions with MTF Cterm was as high (or higher) than that obtained with full-length MTF1 when the concentration of the initiating NTP (ATP) was high.
body_text.section: The MTF1 C-terminal tail contributes to promoter opening

body_text.text: However, at low initiating NTP concentrations the activity in the MTF Cterm reactions was markedly reduced compared to those carried out with full-length protein.
body_text.section: The MTF1 C-terminal tail contributes to promoter opening

body_text.text: A similar difference in activity at high versus low ATP concentrations with MTF Cterm versus full-length MTF1 was not observed on pre-melted promoters ( Supplementary Figure S5B and C).
body_text.section: The MTF1 C-terminal tail contributes to promoter opening

body_text.text: Other measurements, including the sensitivity of ICs to varying salt levels and the rates of dinucleotide synthesis as a function of varying ATP concentrations, similarly indicated a specific deficiency in the activity of MTF Cterm ICs on duplex, but not pre-melted, promoters ( Supplementary Figures S5D and E).
body_text.section: The MTF1 C-terminal tail contributes to promoter opening

body_text.text: Fitting of these data showed apparent K ATP to be 4-8-fold greater with MTF Cterm versus fulllength MTF1 on duplex promoters, but identical within experimental error on pre-melted promoters ( Table 1).

body_text.text: We undertook a similar set of EM studies of the yeast MtR-NAP EC.
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: A synthetic transcription bubble was formed by hybridizing a 10 base RNA to the 5 -segment of a 21 base T-strand annealed to a 21 base NT-strand which was noncomplementary to the 10 bases at the 5 -end of the T-strand (Supplementary Figure S1C; 'EC DNA').
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: Native gel analysis showed that MtRNAP formed a stable complex with this nucleic acid scaffold and extension assays revealed that the RNA was quantitatively extended in a T-strand directed manner by the MtRNAP upon addition of NTPs (Supplementary Figure S1F), confirming that the complexes formed with this scaffold were functional.
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: Both gel analysis and inspection of EM fields revealed that the ECs were highly homogeneous, so we carried out reconstructions of the EC by both cryoEM of unstained, frozen-hydrated particles (9538 particles, 19Å resolution) and negative staining (20 873 particles, 19Å resolution).
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: Both 3D reconstructions were very similar (Figure 5A and B; see also Supplementary Figure S6A and B).
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: We also carried out a 3D reconstruction with negatively-stained particles of an EC assembled with an MtRNAP from which residues 1-243 had been deleted, corresponding to a putative nuclear version of the polymerase that has been dubbed spRNAPIV (32).
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: The 3D reconstruction of the spRNAPIV EC was very similar to the negatively stained or cryoEM reconstructions of the full-length MtRNAP ECs ( Figure 5C; see also Supplementary Figure S6E), with no additional density apparent in the full-length reconstructions that could be clearly assigned to the element deleted in the spRNAPIV EC ( Figure  5A-C).
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: The difference maps obtained by subtracting MtR-NAP EC from spRNAPIV EC also failed to show any obvious density that could be assigned to the region deleted in spRNAPIV.
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: Therefore, it is probably that the N-terminal region deleted in spRNAPIV is either wholly or partially disordered and does not contribute to the density in the averaged 3D reconstructions of the full-length MtRNAP.
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: This would be consistent with what is observed with both human MtRNAP structures (PDB IDs: 4BOC (24) and 3SPA (9)), in which residues 1-105 were deleted to enhance crystallization, and in which residues 106-217 are disordered and invisible in the electron density map (23).
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: The atomic structure of human MtRNAPEC (24) fits well into all of the three 3D reconstructions of EC shown here (Figure 5A-C; see also Supplementary Figure S6A,B and E).
body_text.section: The structure of the yeast MtRNAP elongation complex (EC)

body_text.text: The length and sequences of EC DNA scaffolds used in this study and in the atomic structure of human MtRNAPEC (24) are not identical.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: However, the downstream edge of two transcription bubbles can be used as reference point for alignment, which allows modeling of the position of the EC DNA termini (Figure 5D and E).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: To confirm this, we carried out 3D reconstructions of negatively stained ECs assembled with nucleic acid scaffolds in which either the upstream or downstream DNA ends were labeled with streptavidin (Supplementary Figure S6C and D and Figure 5F and H).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: The difference in the positions of both the upstream and downstream DNA termini as modeled from the human MtRNAP EC structure and as experimentally determined by positions of the streptavidin molecules is ∼15Å (in the case of upstream DNA termini this discrepancy is even smaller as the 5 NT end of DNA used in this study is in the single stranded form, comparing to the corresponding nucleotide at position −10 of DNA in 4BOC).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: Since the resolution of our structures is in the 15-25Å range, this represents excellent quantitative agreement between the human MtRNAP EC crystal structure and our EM reconstructions.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: Using the positions of the streptavidin molecules to compare the positions of the DNA IC and EC reveals a clear displacement of its upstream end during the transition from the IC to EC (Figure 6A and B).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: To test this further we conjugated Fe-BABE to cysteines introduced into the MtR-NAP C-terminal domain on the thumb (at residue 780) and fingers subdomains (at residues 1025, 1074 and 1078), and on the NTD (at residue 493).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: The conjugates on the thumb and fingers subdomains cut DNA either within or immediately downstream of the transcription bubble in both the IC and EC, and generally tracked the downstream movement of the RNAP as the RNA was extended ( Figure 6C; the conjugate on the thumb also showed discontinuous changes in cutting during initial transcription, as is also seen in similar experiments with T7RNAP (13)).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: However, the conjugate on the NTD exhibited cutting in ICs, but not the EC, consistent with the observed displacement of the upstream end of DNA
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: The N-terminal extension domain appears to be involved in formation of the downstream edge of the transcription bubble (33), which led us to ask ourselves if the Nterminal deletion in spRNAPIV might affect DNA binding to EC.
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: To address this, we generated a 3D reconstruction of spRNAPIV and DNA labeled with streptavidin at its downstream end (see Supplementary Figures S6E and F).
body_text.section: Localization of DNA in the EC

body_text.text: In the 3D reconstruction of the spRNAPIV EC the streptavidin molecule is located at a similar position as in the downstream labeled version of the full length MtRNAP EC (compare Figure 5F and G), indicating that the deletion does not grossly alter the position of the downstream DNA.

body_text.text: Pol A class polymerases are characterized by conformational changes during their reaction cycles that involve opening and closing of the central template binding cleft around which these enzymes are organized.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Rotation of the fingers subdomain toward the cleft accompanies binding of NTP or dNTP, while rotation of the fingers away from the cleft, causing it to become more open, occurs upon pyrophosphate release at the end of the nucleotide addition cycle (6)(7)(8)(34)(35)(36).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In addition to this transition, which is common to all pol A class enzymes, individual members of this family display distinct conformational changes, often involving distinct domains N-terminal to the common polymerase domain.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In T7 RNAP, e.g. rotation of the NTD away from the polymerase domain progressively enlarges the template binding cleft to accommodate the growing RNA:DNA hybrid as the RNA is extended during initial transcription (37).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: A subsequent, large-scale conformational change in the NTD occurs upon transition to elongation, and ruptures promoter:RNAP interactions to allow promoter release and movement down the template DNA (7,34,36).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Human MtRNAP, in the absence of DNA or transcription factors, crystallized in a 'clenched' conformation that is more closed than any of the conformational states observed in the homologous T7 RNAP enzyme (23).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Given the conformational malleability of these proteins, it is important to validate the physiological significance of the conformations observed in crystal structures because these conformations can be influenced by packing interactions or extreme crystallization solution conditions.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our EM data indicate that, under near-physiological solution environments, yeast MtRNAP assumes a tightly closed conformation similar to the clenched human MtRNAP state.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The clenched conformation therefore appears to be a physiologically relevant state.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Interestingly, the upstream ends of the DNAs seem to be similarly positioned in the characterized yeast quasi-IC and T7RNAP IC with 0 or 3 nts long RNA.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This could mean that upon binding to MtRNAP, bubble or even duplex promoter DNAs assume a topology similar to the DNAs in the T7RNAP early ICs with 3-nt long RNAs.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: However, as revealed by streptavidin labeling, the upstream end of the promoter in the quasi-IC is positioned far from the AT-rich recognition loop in the NTD of the mtRNAP, and is therefore less bent than the DNA in the IC.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The latter interactions may be required to induce the sharp bending required for promoter opening.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This could also explain why yeast MtRNAP alone is capable of start-ing transcription from bubble promoters, but not from duplex ones.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Additionally, yeast MtRNAP alone binds relatively weakly to DNA and with relatively poor sequence specificity.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: MTF1 increases the stability and sequence specificity of the initiation complex (27,28).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: It is possible that, in the absence of MTF1, MtRNAP assumes a clenched conformation that associates weakly and non-specifically with DNA so that it can efficiently scan DNA for promoter sequences ( Figure 7, quasi-IC).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Encounter with a promoter could transiently slow this scanning to allow MTF1 binding, inducing the isomerization to the open state coupled with an increase of the DNA bending in the complex, as revealed by the different positions of streptavidin in this study, and consistent with previously reported differential bending of promoter DNA by yeast MtRNAP alone versus the yeast MtRNAP:MTF1 complex (28).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our EM data reveal how the MtRNAP and the MTF1 engage to form a functional IC, indicating that the upstream end of the DNA is brought into close proximity with the AT rich recognition loop of the NTD, which, together with MTF1, form a specific binding site for the upstream (−4 to −9 bp) promoter sequence (Figure 7, IC).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: As is also seen in T7RNAP, sequence specific binding of the promoter would therefore involve the NTD(s) and the promoter recognition loop (12,26), but would also involve MTF1, which generates promoter specificity through the conformational changes it induces in the polymerase and possibly also by making direct, sequencespecific interactions with the promoter.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The sharp bending of the promoter in the IC complex would bring the DNA closer to the AT rich recognition loop, which would have a stabilizing effect on the MtRNAP:MTF1:DNA complex and would help drive promoter melting (28), as would interactions between MTF1 and the unwound NT strand (38), and between the MTF1 C-terminal tail and the melted regions of the promoter (39).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Published data do not clearly define the interaction between MtRNAP and MTF1.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Deletions of the N-terminal and the C-terminal regions of MTF1 resulted in the absence or decreased yield of IC (40), suggesting the involvement of multiple regions in the MtRNAP:MTF1 interaction.

body_text.text: Genetic screening has led to the identification of point mutations that cause loss or drastic decrease in mitochondrial transcription.

body_text.text: However, mutations R178A/K179A and H187A/R189A, which are located in the basic cleft at the interface of NH2 and COOH terminal subdomains, were previously shown to inactivate transcription on linear but not supercoiled DNA promoters (41), but are not accommodated in this model.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: A low-resolution structure of the human mtRNAP IC generated by EM and image processing has been recently reported (42) which reveals a completely different position for the transcription factors than that observed in this work for MTF1.

body_text.text: However, we believe that the mentioned work suffers from certain problems, among others the low number of particles used in the study and the absence of any experimental evidence regarding the location of the individual components which could have led to an incorrect organization of the IC (Supplementary Figure S7D and E).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our structural study provides a more precise and in-depth insight into the organization of IC state, complementing and allowing the evaluation of information gathered by biochemical and biophysical approaches (25,39,43,44).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Thus, our EM study shows for the first time how these two proteins interact and, furthermore, excludes these hypothetical models, as the region 3 and the remaining superficially exposed amino acids of region 1 and 2 are placed at the opposite, outer face of MTF1.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Additionally, our data places the positively charged cleft of MTF1 toward the MtRNAP and the DNA (Supplementary Figure S7B and C).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Transcription initiation requires the formation of stable and specific interactions between the RNAP and the promoter, which lead to its bending and tension accumulation.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This tension is released through the promoter melting and formation of the upstream edge of transcription bubble, generally in the AT rich regions of the promoters.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In T7 RNAP three structural elements-(1) the AT rich recognition loop (residues 93-101); (2) the specificity loop (residues 739-770); and (3) the intercalating ␤hairpin including Val237 (residues 230-245) are responsible for the promoter recognition, binding and melting.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: RNAPs remains bound to their promoters as the RNA is extended to a length that triggers promoter release and transition to elongation.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The T7RNAP IC to EC transition involves large structural rearrangement of the entire NTD and specificity loop, resulting in the loss of all contacts with the promoter and the formation of the RNA exit channel (34).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The C-terminal, catalytic domain undergoes fewer conformational changes.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our EM reconstructions of MtRNAP IC and EC reveal that, consistent with what has been previously observed (9,24), that the N-terminal part of protein, unlike in T7RNAP, does not change conformation during the IC-EC transition ( Figure  7, EC).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Unlike what is seen with T7RNAP, promoter release and transition to elongation do not depend on conformational changes in the promoter binding elements of the mtRNAP.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Instead, MtRNAPs recruit dissociable transcription factor(s) which, in the initiation phase of transcription drive a transition from a clenched to an open conformation in the mtRNAP, and allow for promoter recognition, melting and stabilization of the IC.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Subsequently, these factors become displaced and allow promoter release once the RNA reaches a length sufficient for formation of a stable MtRNAP:DNA:RNA complex.
